metadata.name: Nuages possibles #82
metadata.description:
Stippling clouds imagined by a computer.

Each cloud is a "Nuage possible"

It may be generated from code,
but these clouds might have existed,
or might exist in the future,
just for a brief moment.


Those images were inspired by Joanie Lemercier’s cloud series, an algorithm is imagining more and more variations of those skyscapes in an infinite quest for the perfect cloud.

Once created from code, the drawings are made by a plotter machine, a little robot that moves a pen over black paper to lay down dots of white ink. The robot is like an extension of the artist’s arm, allowing him to create infinite iterations and variations.

The dots pattern and their density help create the illusion of shadows, gradients and brightness, a technique inherited from the pointillism movement, born in Belgium and France in the late 19th century.

metadata.name: Waiting in Afton #47
metadata.description: One image for each day since I quit my job as a data engineer to work on art full-time. Looking out my back window each day and watching the seasons change.

metadata.name: Textiles #32
metadata.description:
This project attempts to emulate the rich textures of textiles.


High quality export :

Due to the fact that the rendering process is quite CPU/GPU intensive, higher resolution images are divided into tiles. To select the resolution use the following key commands

1 : 1024 x 1024 (1 tile)
2 : 2048 x 2048 (4 tiles)
4 : 4096 x 4096 (16 tiles)
8 : 8192 x 8192 (64 tiles)

To export a tile, press p. Selecting a resolution will restart the tile position to 0. Tiles are ordered column-major order.

metadata.name: Smooth Steps #251
metadata.description:
Mostly dark. 

Custom software (color, silent) Variable dimensions, horizontal or vertical HTML, JavaScript, WebGL

Keys

i : Toggle info
1-4 : Display density (select 1 if slow)
q : Toggle quality
f : Full-screen

Some settings can be adjusted through the URL query string: more info in the HTML source.

Press p to save a hi-res image.

Press any other key to toggle between two views. Please note that this change will not happen instantaneously, as it will take a number of seconds for the code to run.

metadata.name: Redivision #19
metadata.description:
My first mint on fx(hash) together with HEK - Haus der elektronischen Künste, is a revisit of my early explorations of computational geometry which I had started in 2008 when my tool of choice was still Flash and ActionScript. Since Flash does not exist anymore most of what I had created over a course of 12 years is almost impossible to view in its original form these days and large parts of my beginnings in generative art are lost in time now.

In these early experiments I started building my personal generative library QuasimondoLibs which consisted of a ever growing set of algorithms for geometry and pixel manipulation. Over the years I had ported most my library to Javascript and Python and this work uses the JS version of it.

In my subdivision series I explored the many ways recursion can be applied to geometric shapes, starting with simple convex shapes and then expanding into non-convex or curved ones.

In "Redivision" I modernized one of my early codes and adapted it for the use with fx(hash) features.

metadata.name: monogrid 1.1 CE #154
metadata.description:
Each monogrid artwork gets initialized with a start up algorithm that builds up a set of rectangles and fills them with pixels. There are two different styles, 'Pixel' and 'Line', to create the initial image.

There is a set of 16 animations at work. 4 noise based animations, 4 shifting animations, 4 modulo based animation and 4 reset animations, all run in parallel. Each animation selects a rectangle from the initial setup and edits the pixels in this area. The selection process runs independently and animations can overlap which results in a new style of animation.

monogrid 1.1 is based on the original series at https://monogrid.xyz, but there are no black/white versions included. The color palette is a mixture of one of 12 colors plus black or white.
The fragment shader has been updated in the way the 16 different animations get summed up. This version would appear more chaotic and organic.

monogrid 1.1 - Collectors Edition
Kim Asendorf, 2022

metadata.name: Crossing Paths #9
metadata.description:
Crossing Paths

An ode to the crossing paths in life.

Crossing Paths was created inspired by La Longue Marche (1974), a series of acrylic paintings made by Julio Le Parc.

by @code2pixels
May, 2022

Made with p5.js, p5.js-func and bezier.js

--------------------------

RESOLUTION  
Press a number from '1' to '9' to render in various resolutions, being 1, the smallest, and 9 the highest. 

EXPORT IMAGE
Open live and press 's'

metadata.name: NOMADS #56
metadata.description:
NOMADS tells a story through each of its editions: the migration of a population, following simple rules, and whose movements reveal complex shapes and textures, both visual and auditory.
Movement, order, chaos, borders, convergence, wandering, rotation... it's all part of NOMADS

Enjoy the journey as much as the destination


KEYBOARD SHORCUTS:
[S]: Redraw the art and save a 4K PNG
[L]: Toggle between "Infinite Loop" and "Single Render" modes
[M]: Toggle mute

MOUSE / TOUCHSCREEN:
[Click / Tap]: Toggle mute
[Double Click / Double Tap]: Save the current render

URL PARAMETERS:
?start : bypass the intro timer and start the rendering
?loop : select the "Infinite Loop" mode by default
?resolution=1920x1080 : render in a custom resolution using the format WIDTHxHEIGHT. Different aspect ratios will produce different results.
?frame=0.1 : control the frame size around the canvas (value between 0 and 1)
?save : automatically save the image when the rendering is done


Artist: Estienne
Oct. 2022
NFT 2.0 License

Best viewed on Chrome or Chromium based browser
Tested on Chrome v 106.0.5249.119

Libraries used:
p5.js
Tone.js

metadata.name: forest #62

metadata.name: Barriers #104
metadata.description:
Barriers is an artwork+data visualization about the state of LGBT+ rights across the world.

Each edition is assigned 1 out of 197 countries. Four basic LGBT+ rights are represented as circles with barriers. The largest circle signifies whether homosexual activity is legal. The second-largest signifies same-sex marriage. The third one, same-sex adoption. The smallest one is the legality of gender change. One barrier means full rights. The more barriers, the more unequal rights are afforded to LGBT+ people.

The colors of the edition signify the country’s region and subregion.

The artwork adapts to different screen sizes and ratios, so I recommend exploring it on various devices or resizing your browser window.

· Interactions in-depth ·

Desktop - S for save / D for dark mode / A for animate again

Mobile - Long press for save / Double tap for dark mode / Quadruple tap for animate again

Created using p5js and FettePalette. Data is from Equaldex.

attributes.name: Same-sex Adoption
attributes.value: No data, no laws, n/a, or ambiguous

metadata.name: Release #13
metadata.description:
[…]

More than anything she had wanted to show him where she had lived, where, at a specific time every year, endless fields sent a new cycle of pods on their way.

She preferred to experience these moments alone, imagining the spectacle was being performed just for her. The whole act carried a promise of new beginnings, of paths yet to be taken.

She wasn't really part of any of this, but she too had the coordinates to her own life programmed into her genes.

Any decision would be true now, any path free.

A chorus of explosions sounded as the field burst open.

[…]

–

You can append these parameters to the URL:

[scale=<number>] scale the renderer.
[long-side=<number>] define the number of pixels of the longest side.
[animation=false] skip animating the lines.
[mode=monotone] activate monotone mode.
[detail=<number 0–1>] coarser (0) or finer (1) lines, default: 0.5.

Press [control / command + s] or [tap and hold] to save the current frame.
	- in normal mode: PNG file.
	- in monotone mode: SVG file, suitable for plotting.

Note: The monotone SVG file has no defined dimensions. It is suitable for plotting at 30 × 30 cm. with a 0.25 mm. pen tip. When plotting in larger sizes, you can increase the [detail] parameter to keep contrast with the same pen.

© 2022 Monokai.

metadata.name: Joy Spaces #22
metadata.description:
Sharing a space that fills us with happiness
    Exploring what is deeply inside 
    Thinking as one and thinking as hive
    We play
    A doing so we transcend

    I know you as you know me
    You explore as I explore
    Mirrors of fears to grow
    Mirrors of love to embrace
    Let's keep on as we can
    Discovering the unknown
    That explodes inside each of us
    And is asking to be felt



Controls: 's' - canvas save

Crafted to be seen in Google Chrome 107.0.5304.107

Released on fx(hash) to celebrate the first birthday of this platform that has transformed our lives and our culture. Thank you mates, developers, artist and collectors. It has been a great year and I hope is the first of many to came. 


(c) Victor Doval; all rights reserved
